{

  "log": null,
  "summary": "This issue is a question about R's local modifications to the tre library (additional tre_reg* functions and other changes) and whether those changes should be upstreamed. It reports missing symbols when trying to use the standalone tre library with R's modifications on ARM, but does not describe a defect in tre itself, provide a reproducible failure, or point to a confirmed bug or crash. Therefore it is a compatibility/portability/feature inquiry rather than a report of a concrete bug in tre." 
}

{
  "number": "15",
  "is_real_bug": true,
  "is_fixed": false,
  "found_pointer": [
    {
      "type": "Other",
      "value": "tre-compile.c:1249 (static analysis warning: Logical disjunction always evaluates to true)"
    }
  ],
  "fixed_pointer": [],
  "bug_kind": "OTHER",
  "how_found": "STATIC_ANALYSIS",
  "reproduction_pattern_and_input": [],
  "log": null,
  "summary": "The report points out a logic error in an assertion in tre-compile.c where 'assert(lit->code_max >= 1 || lit->code_max <= ASSERT_LAST);' is always true, and the author suggests it should be '&&'. This is a real source-code bug (a faulty assertion) discovered via a static-analysis warning; it makes the assertion ineffective. It is categorized as OTHER because it is a code correctness bug rather than a regex semantic, crash, or performance issue; no fix is indicated in the issue."
}

  "summary": "The reporter cannot build the Python extension on Windows (MSVC) due to missing tre headers and then linker unresolved externals for tre_* symbols; this is a real build/linking bug (packaging/build issue) rather than a misuse. The issue was discovered by the user while manually building (MANUAL_REVIEW). A commenter states they have a fix in their branch that makes it work, so a fix exists though no commit/PR or version is provided. No explicit reproduction pattern (regex) applies; the log above contains the exact compile/linker errors extracted from the report."
}

  "summary": "This issue is an announcement of a third-party PyPI package for tre; comments report a pip install/build failure complaining that the C header 'tre/tre.h' is missing. The report indicates a packaging or distribution problem with that PyPI package (and the maintainer states they no longer maintain it), not a defect in the tre regex engine itself. There is no indication of a bug in the tre codebase or any fix provided in the thread, so this is not classified as a real bug for the engine repository."
}

  "summary": "This issue is a user question asking whether TRE supports partial-from-start matching, not a report of incorrect behavior. The maintainer responded that the feature is already possible and gave an example (`^(a/b/c/d){-4}`), so there is no bug to fix. Therefore it is not classified as a real bug."
}

{
  "number": "26",
  "is_real_bug": true,
  "is_fixed": false,
  "found_pointer": [
    {
      "type": "Other",
      "value": "agrep.c, line 43 and line 57 (source snippets showing short_options and long_options)"
    }
  ],
  "fixed_pointer": [],
  "bug_kind": "SEMANTIC",
  "how_found": "MANUAL_REVIEW",
  "reproduction_pattern_and_input": [],
  "log": null,
  "summary": "The reporter found that the short option -d is defined to take an argument (short_options contains 'd:'), but the long option --delimiter is declared with no_argument in long_options, causing --delimiter=PATTERN to be rejected. This is a real bug in the program's option parsing (inconsistent option metadata), discovered by manual inspection of the source (agrep.c). There is no indication in the issue that it has been fixed or which version is affected, so is_fixed is false and no fixed pointer is provided."
}

{
  "number": "27",
  "is_real_bug": false,
  "is_fixed": false,
  "found_pointer": [],
  "fixed_pointer": [],
  "bug_kind": null,
  "how_found": null,
  "reproduction_pattern_and_input": [],
  "log": null,
  "summary": "The reporter observed that ./configure failed because ChangeLog had been renamed; they worked around it by copying ChangeLog.old. A maintainer replied that ./configure does not require ChangeLog unless automake was invoked manually without the --foreign option instead of using the documented ./utils/autogen.sh. This indicates a build-usage mistake (running automake incorrectly), not an inherent bug in the tre project, so the report does not describe a real bug."
}

{
  "number": "28",
  "is_real_bug": true,
  "is_fixed": true,
  "found_pointer": [
    {
      "type": "Version",
      "value": "tre-0.8.0p0"
    },
    {
      "type": "Version",
      "value": "tre-0.8.0"
    }
  ],
  "fixed_pointer": [
    {
      "type": "Other",
      "value": "current version"
    }
  ],
  "bug_kind": "SEMANTIC",
  "how_found": "MANUAL_REVIEW",
  "reproduction_pattern_and_input": [
    {
      "pattern": "datormagazin",
      "input": "eW91dHViZSBuaWxzb2xhYXhlbAp2aW1lbyBuaWxzb2xhQGFiYy5zZSAKbz8/4oCZcmVpbGx5
IGhlbUBuaWxzb2xhLnNlIApkYXRvcm1hZ2F6aW4gZG16bGFicyBtZWRpYXNob3cgbmlsc29s
YQo="
    },
    {
      "pattern": "vimeo",
      "input": "eW91dHViZSBuaWxzb2xhYXhlbAp2aW1lbyBuaWxzb2xhQGFiYy5zZSAKbz8/4oCZcmVpbGx5
IGhlbUBuaWxzb2xhLnNlIApkYXRvcm1hZ2F6aW4gZG16bGFicyBtZWRpYXNob3cgbmlsc29s
YQo="
    }
  ],
  "log": "When agrep’ing a file with some odd characters on one
line the search seems to stop at that line and nothing
is found therafter.

Furhter info:
export LC_ALL=en_US.UTF-8
  <the trouble described below>
export LC_ALL=en_US.ISO8859-1
  <work as expected!>
unset LC_ALL
  <work as expected!>

so it seems to be a problem related to utf-8

I have reduced this to a testfile that I paste here in b64, 
it is only 4 lines:
eW91dHViZSBuaWxzb2xhYXhlbAp2aW1lbyBuaWxzb2xhQGFiYy5zZSAKbz8/4oCZcmVpbGx5
IGhlbUBuaWxzb2xhLnNlIApkYXRvcm1hZ2F6aW4gZG16bGFicyBtZWRpYXNob3cgbmlsc29s
YQo=

The simple testcase is simply like this:
  $ /usr/bin/grep datormagazin /tmp/test
  datormagazin dmzlabs mediashow nilsola
  $ echo $?
  0
  $ /usr/local/bin/agrep datormagazin /tmp/test
  $ echo $?
  1

...

match on line before, strange behaviour:
  $ /usr/bin/grep vimeo /tmp/test
  vimeo nilsola@abc.se
  $ /usr/local/bin/agrep vimeo /tmp/test
  vimeo nilsola@abc.se 
  o���reilly hem@nilsola.se 
  datormagazin dmzlabs mediashow nilsola
  s%
  $ echo $?
  0
",
  "summary": "The reporter observed agrep (tre) failing to find matches after a line containing odd/UTF-8 characters (examples with patterns 'datormagazin' and 'vimeo') when LC_ALL was set to en_US.UTF-8; the behavior worked correctly under ISO8859-1 or when LC_ALL unset. This is a real semantic bug (incorrect matching behavior in a UTF-8 locale) observed on tre-0.8.0 and tre-0.8.0p0. A project member commented that it "appears to work as expected in the current version," so the issue appears to have been fixed (comment does not name a specific version or commit). Reproduction data includes the provided base64 4-line testfile and the shell reproduction shown in the report."
}

{
  "number": "36",
  "is_real_bug": true,
  "is_fixed": false,
  "found_pointer": [],
  "fixed_pointer": [],
  "bug_kind": "SEMANTIC",
  "how_found": "MANUAL_REVIEW",
  "reproduction_pattern_and_input": [
    {
      "pattern": "*_abc",
      "input": "_abc"
    }
  ],
  "log": null,
  "summary": "The report states that repeat operators are accepted at the start of a pattern (example: \"*_abc\") and that regcomp accepts and matches it, whereas documentation and other engines treat leading repeat operators as a compile error. This is a real semantic/parsing bug because the engine accepts an invalid pattern and interprets it rather than reporting a syntax error. The issue has no indication of being fixed and was discovered by manual testing; the provided reproducible case is pattern \"*_abc\" matching input \"_abc\"."
}

The maintainer instructed to install autoconf/automake/autopoint/libtool/gettext and run utils/autogen.sh, the reporter did that and later confirmed the project compiled. This is a user setup/usage issue rather than a defect in the tre codebase, so it does not qualify as a real bug."
}

{
  "number": "42",
  "is_real_bug": true,
  "is_fixed": false,
  "found_pointer": [],
  "fixed_pointer": [],
  "bug_kind": "MEMORY",
  "how_found": "MANUAL_REVIEW",
  "reproduction_pattern_and_input": [],
  "log": null,
  "summary": "The report describes a real memory-safety bug: when printing a delimiter the code subtracts delim_len from the record pointer without ensuring there are that many bytes before record in the buffer, causing out-of-bounds bytes (garbage) to be printed. This is a memory bug (reading outside the buffer). The reporter states they added a test checking record - buf >= delim_len, but no commit/PR or version is provided and no fix is indicated in the issue. Classification and fields are based only on the explicit description in the report."
}

}

  "number": "52",

      "input": null
    }
  ],
  "log": "==24104==ERROR: AddressSanitizer: SEGV on unknown address 0x000000000000 (pc 0x00000051f502 bp 0x000000000000 sp 0x7ffc522f13c0 T0)\n==24104==The signal is caused by a READ memory access.\n==24104==Hint: address points to the zero page.\n    #0 0x51f501 in tre_match_empty lib/tre-compile.c:1256:17\n    #1 0x511a3e in tre_compute_nfl lib/tre-compile.c:1488:12\n    #2 0x511a3e in tre_compile lib/tre-compile.c:1997\n    #3 0x530464 in tre_regncomp lib/regcomp.c:93:9\n    #4 0x50c7af in main src/agrep.c:743:13\n",
  "summary": "The report describes a null-pointer dereference (crash) when running agrep with the pattern \"{+}{7}\"; an AddressSanitizer stack trace is included showing tre_match_empty in lib/tre-compile.c. This is a real bug (segfault) and is categorized as CRASH; the report states it was discovered using LLVM's LibFuzzer. No version, commit, or fix pointer is provided in the issue, so I marked it unfixed and left found/fixed pointers empty. Reproduction pattern \"{+}{7}\" is extracted; no input string was provided in the report."
}

    }

  "summary": "The report describes an infinite loop (hang) when running agrep with a pattern containing a back-reference: echo 'xx' | ./src/agrep '(\\\\0|x)+'. This is a real bug because it causes non-termination of matching (a performance/hang issue) and the reporter states it was found with LLVM's LibFuzzer. No version, commit, or fix is provided in the report, so is_fixed is false and no pointers could be extracted."
}

  "summary": "The reporter used AFL to fuzz agrep linked with tre and supplied a repository with inputs that cause crashes. Valgrind output included in the report shows invalid reads (tre_match_empty) leading to SIGSEGV and many "conditional jump depends on uninitialised value(s)" warnings in tre_parse, indicating memory-safety issues. This is a real bug (memory bug) found via fuzzing; no fix or patch is mentioned in the issue. Reproduction artifacts are provided in the linked repo (the "random" input file); exact pattern is not shown in the issue."
}

  "log": null,
  "summary": "The report compares PCRE behaviour (grep -P recognizes \\d) with tre's POSIX ERE interpretation where backslash escapes are not special inside bracket expressions, so '[\\d.]' matches backslash, 'd', or '.' rather than a digit. Commenters explain the correct POSIX usage ([[:digit:].]) and that agrep/tre uses POSIX ERE semantics, so the observed behavior is expected rather than a bug. This is a usage/semantics misunderstanding, not a defect in tre, and the issue was marked a duplicate of #20."
}

The issue includes a suggested parser change (lib/tre-parse.c line 631) but no explicit fix or commit is provided in the report, so it is not marked fixed."
}

This constitutes a real semantic/differential bug (different match results). No indication in the report that it was fixed or which version/commit was used, and the issue was discovered by comparing results with glibc."
}

  "summary": "The reporter observed truncated/missing matches when running agrep on tidy1to2.csv; maintainer reproduced and investigated, showing the file contains truncated UTF-8 sequences (incomplete multi-byte 0xC3 sequences). Agrep returns incorrect counts and omits entries while GNU grep handles the corrupted encoding more gracefully, so this is a real bug in agrep's handling of encoding errors (semantic incorrect matching). The issue was diagnosed via manual inspection and command-line tests; no fix or commit is mentioned in the thread."
